bibl.title: Sacred Stories of the Sweet Grass Cree
bibl.series: National Museum of Canada, Bulletin no. 60, Anthropological Series, no. 11

encodingdesc.p: This electronic document is oriented more toward representing those features that seem most likely to be relevant for grammatical analyses, rather than toward faithfully representing all the information available in the book.

list.item: 2014 06 10; KR; UTF-8, paragraph and sentence numbering, smart-quotes in English translations

p.seg: kîtahtawê yâhkih mîna mitâtasiwak nâpêwak . Once upon a time, of old, there were ten men.

âsay mîna tapasîwak ,
osâm kika-mêscihikonaw awa wîhtikôw , êh-itwêcik êsah . Again, they fled, saying, “That Windigo would destroy us all.”
pêyak oskinîkiskwêsisah sipwêhtahêwak , osîmisiwâwa . As they went away, they took with them a young girl, their younger sister.
nikwatis êsa ntawih-osîhtâwak wîkiwâw . Off alone somewhere they went and built their dwelling.
êkwah êkotê ay-ayâwak . And off there they stayed.
êkwah kinwês êkotê êsah oy-ôhpikihêwak ôhih osîmisiwâwa . And there for a long time they must have been bringing up their sister.

piyisk ispimihk êsa mistikwah cimahêwak , êkotah êh-mânokawâcik , êh-wacistwanihkêcik , itah êh-owîkiyit . Finally they set up in the ground a tall tree, and in it they built a lodge, making a kind of nest, in which she then had her dwelling.
kîtahtawê kahkiyaw kêkway êsah pawâtam awa kanâc-ôskinîkiskwêw . Then, in time, that pure maiden must have seen all manner of things in her dreams.
êkwah kîtahtawê kâ-kiskêyihtahk kitah-pimihât . Then, presently, she knew that she could fly.
êkwah kotakah nâpêsisah minah osîmisiw êsah awa oskinîkiskwêw . And there was a little boy, a brother still younger than this young woman.

êkwah ômisi k-êtât osîmisah :
niwîh-ntâmison , itwêw êsah . Then she said to her younger brother, “I shall gather berries.”

seg.gloss: “Big sister, but where will you find any berries?

p.seg: pipon ôma , itwêw êsah awa nâpêsis . It is winter,” said the little boy.
nisîmis , namoya nika-kîh-pwâtawihtân , itwêw êsah ; “Little brother, not by any chance shall I fail,” she said;
ayisk nika-pimihân , itwêw êsah awa oskinîkiskwêw . “For I shall fly,” said the young woman.
êkwa tâpwê wawêyîw , ê-sipwêhtêt , kotak askiy êy-isi-pimihât awa oskinîkiskwêw . Then really the young woman dressed herself and set out and flew to another land.
tâpwê êkotê êh-takohtêt akâmaskihk , mâci-mawisôw . Really, when she arrived there across the sea, she began to gather berries.
katisk êsah êh-âpihtâ-kîsikâyik êkotê takohtêw . She arrived there exactly at noon.
âsay mâci-mawisôw misâskwatôminah . She began to gather saskatoon berries.

pêyak mwêhci ê-sâkaskinahtât omawiswâkan , âsay mîna kotak êh-atih-sâkaskinahtât , kîtahtawê piyêsiwah kâ-pêhtâkosiyit . When she had filled one of her berrying baskets and was setting about filling the other, suddenly a Thunderer's roar was heard.
kayahtê nâspici-sêkimik . It frightened her out of her senses.
êh-pêkopayit , kayahtê kâ-wâh-waniskânikot oskinîkiwa . When she awoke, to her surprise, a youth was raising her to her feet.
mistah êkwah êkotah miywêyihtam . She was very glad.
mâh-mâsihitôwak ; owîcimosiw ôhi oskinîkiwah . [no translation]
êh-otâkosiniyik iyikohk , kîwêw . Towards evening, she went home.
tâpwê mînisah kîwêhtatâw . So really, she brought berries.
wîkiwâhk êh-takohtêt , mâcih-kîsisam ôhih mînisah . When she arrived at their dwelling, she set about stewing the berries.
mistah êkwah miywêyihtamiyiwa ostêsah ê-kîsisamôwât . Her elder brothers were very much pleased when she gave them the stewed berries.
tânitê êtokê wêhtinahk kisîminaw ôhi mînisah ? itwêwak ôki oskinîkiwak . “Where can our sister have got these berries?” asked the youths.

mâmaskâtamwak ; oski-mînisah êh-mîcicik êh-piponiyik ohcih , k-ôh-mâmaskâtahkik , êkwah wiyah kâkikê ispimihk wacistwanihk awa oskinîkiskwêw êh-owîkit . They marvelled at this, that in winter they were eating fresh berries, and because that young woman always had her dwelling up aloft in the nest.

âsay mayaw êh-waniskâcik , sipwêhtêwak ôki oskinîkiwak , wiyah tahto-kîsikâw pikoh êh-mâcîcik , êh-is-âtoskêcik , kahkiyaw kêkway êh-mâcîtotawâcik . As soon as the young man got up, they went away, for every day they did nothing but hunt, for this was their work, to hunt every kind of creature.
âsay mîna oskinîkiskwêw nîhtakosiw . Again the young woman came down.

âsay mîna ômis îtêw osîmisah ôhi nâpêsisah :
mînah niwîhntâmison , itwêw êsah awa oskinîkiskwêw . Again she said to the boy, her brother, “I am going berrying again,” said the young woman.
tâpwêh âsay mîna sipwêhtêw awa oskinîkiskwêw , êh-pimihât . Accordingly, again the young woman set out, flying.
âsay mîna akâmaskihk takohtêw . Again she arrived in the land across the sea.
âsay mîna êkotê itah kâ-kîh-ohtinahk mînisah mâci-mawisôw mîna . Again in the place from which she had taken berries, she set about her berrying.
pôtih âsay mîna pêyakwâw ê-sâkaskinahtât omawiswâkan , âsay mîna piyêsiwa kâ-pêhtâkosiyit . Behold, when again she had filled one berrying basket, again the Thunderer's noise was heard.
mîna nâspici-sêkimik . Again he frightened her out of her senses.
kayahtê piko mîna sâsay kâ-wâpamât , êh-âpahkawisit ôhi oskinîkiwah kâ-kîh-wâpamât . Again she saw, when she came to, that youth whom she had seen.
âsay mîna mâh-mâsihitôwak . [no translation]
êkotah kapê-kîsik ay-ayâwak . They stayed there all day,
ayisk miywêyimêw ôhih oskinîkiwah . for she liked that youth.
êy-otâkosiniyik âsay mîna wawêyîw ê-wîh-kîwêt . Towards evening again she made ready to return home.
kîwêw , mîna êh-atih-pimihât . She went home, again flying.
kêkâc êsa êh-tipiskâyik , wîkiwâhk takohtêw . When it was nearly dark, she came to their dwelling.
âsay mîna mâci-kîsisam mînisah . Again she set about stewing berries.
âsay mîna âmaciwêw . Again she went up aloft.
mistahi miywêyihtamwak mâna ôki oskinîkiwak , mînisah miyîcitwâwi . Those young men were always very glad when they had berries to eat.
êkwah mayaw êh-wâpaniyik , âsay mîna mâcîwak . As soon as the next day broke, again they went hunting.

mayaw ostêsah êh-kî-sipwêhtêyit , âsay mîna pê-pinasiwêw aw ôskinîkiskwêw , êh-pi-nânapâcihtawât otayôwinisiyiwa , omaskisiniyiwa mîna . As soon as her elder brothers had departed, the young woman came down again, to attend to their clothes and their moccasins.
pêyakwâw mîna niwîh-ntâmison , itêw êsah osîmisah . “Once more I shall go a-berrying,” she must have told her little brother.
tâpwê sâsay mina wawayîw . Accordingly, again she set forth.
êkwa êsah mina êkotê takohtêw ; Again she arrived at yonder place;
mâcimawisôw itêh kâ-nâ-ntamisot . she set about berrying where twice before she had found berries.
âsay mîna pêyakwâw ê-sâkaskinahtât omawiswâkan , âsay mîna sôhkih kâ-pêhtâkosiyit piyêsiwah . Again when once she had filled a berry-basket, again the thunderer made himself loudly heard.
kayahtê piko mîna kâ-kiskêyihtahk , iyikohk êh-âpahkawisit , êkotah mîna mâh-mâsihitôwak . And when again suddenly she had regained her senses, when she had come to, [no translation]
êw-otâkosiniyik , sâsay mîna kîwêhtatâw mînisah . Towards evening, again she took home berries.
êkwah mîna mâci-kîsisam . Again she set about stewing them.
ê-kîh-kîsisahk mînisah , kâwi âmaciwêw owacistwanihk . When she had stewed the berries, she went back up into her nest.
ê-takoktêcik , mâmaskâtamok ôki oskinîkiwak , tahto-kîsikâw êh-mîcicik oski-mînisah . When they arrived, the young men marvelled that every day they ate fresh berries.

ômisih êsah itwêwak :
tântêh êtokê êh-ohtinahk awa kisîmisinaw oski-mînisah ? itwêwak âsah . They said, “Whence does our sister get fresh berries?”
â , âsay mîna mayaw êh-wâpaniyik , sipwêhtêwak , ê-kîh-mîcisocik . Again, as soon as day had dawned, they set out, having eaten.

kahkiyaw sâsay mîna êh-kîh-mêsci-sipwêhtêyit , awa oskinîkiskwêw âsay mîna wîhtamawêw osîmisah mîn ê-wîh-sipwêhtêt . Again, when every one of them had departed, the young woman told her little brother that she was going off once more.
tâpwê sâsay mîna ati-sipwêhtêw êsah , êh-ati-pimihât . Accordingly, once more she set out and flew.

êkotê êh-takohtêt itêh mânah kây-isi-ntâmisot , mwêhcih êh-mâcih-mawisot , âsay êsah mînah piyêsiwah kâ-mâci-pêhtâkosiyit . When she arrived there where she had been gathering berries, just as she began to pick, again the thunderer began to give his sound.
âsay mîna nâspic-sêkimik awa oskinîkiskwêw . Again the young woman was frightened out of her senses by his sound.
êkwah êh-âpahkawisit , kayahtê kîh-wâpamêw mîna êkotê oskinîkiwa . And when she came to, once more she saw there the youth.
miywêyihtam mistahi aw oskinîkiw , êh-wâw-otihtikot ôhi oskinîkiskwêwa . That youth was very glad that the young woman always came there to him. ?? better normalization for the reduplication?
macikah aciyâ pikoh êh-kîh-mâh-mâsihitocik , âsay mîna kîwêw aw ôskinîkiskwêw . [no translation]
âtah ê-takohtêt wîkiwâhk , namwâc kaskihôw kita-ki-kîhcêkosît kâ-wîkit owacistwanihk . Though she arrived at their dwelling, she was not at all able to climb up to the nest in which she lodged.
âtah wâh-kîhcêkosîcih , pwâtawihôw . Whenever she tried to climb, she failed.
ntawâc nahapiw cîkih iskwâhtêmihk . She needs sat down by the door.
tânêhk ôma ? itêyihtam . “What can be the matter?” she thought.

ayisk ohcitaw êtokê tôtâkôwisiw awa oskinîkiskwêw , osâm mistahih êh-kihcêyimikot ôhih ostêsah , êh-kikiskawâwasot êsah . The fact was, no doubt, that this young woman was so treated by the Higher Powers of purpose, because she was thought too much of by her elder brothers; [no translation]

mayaw awa ostêsimâw êh-takohtêt wîkiwâhk , êsah êh-paspâpit , awîna ôhih , kîh-wâpamêw osîmiwâwa êh-apiyit , êh-kikiskawâwasoyit . As soon as the eldest brother arrived at their lodge, he must have peeped in, and what did he see but their young sister sitting there, [no translation]
namwâc ahpôh pîhtokêw , iyikohk êh-nêpêwisit awa oskinîkiw . He did not even go in, so shamed was that youth.
mistahi pakwâtam . He was deeply grieved.
namoya kiskêyimêwak wîhkâc nâpêwa kita-kîh-wâpamâyit . [no translation]
kotak mîna êh-takohtêt , têpiyâhk êh-wâpamât , êkos îsi wâyonîw . When the next one arrived, as soon as he saw her, he turned back.
kahkiyaw êsah kîh-nakatêwak ôki oskinîkiwak , osâm êh-nêpêwihikocik êh-tôtamiyit . All those young men left her, because she had too much shamed them by what she had done.
kêkâc êsah êh-wâpaniyik , ocawâsimisiw aw oskinîkiskwêw . When dawn had almost come, the young woman bore her child.
ôhi pikoh osîmisah , nâpêsisah , êyakonih piko wîc-âyâmêw . she had with her only her little brother, that boy.
mwêhci nîsosâp tipiskâw êh-pêyakocik , êkwah ômis îtêw ; When they had been alone twelve days and nights, she spoke to him as follows;
ayisk aw îskwêw k-ôcawâsimisit nâpêsisah ayâwêw : for that woman's child was a boy:
niwîh-nikohtân , itêw êsah osîmisah . I am going to gather wood,” she told her little brother.

nâspic ispimihk akotawêw , ômisih âsah êh-itêyihtahk :
nka-kakwê-sipwêhtân , êh-itêyihtahk ês âwa oskinîkiskwêw . she hung them up high, out of his reach, for, “I shall try to go away,” that young woman must have been thinking.
tâpwêh it êh-sakâhk êh-takohtêt , wanakwayah kikamohêw mistikohk ; So, when she came to the grove of trees, she fastened her sleeve to a tree;
ayîsiyinîhkânah osîhêw . she made an effigy of a human being.

awa ôtah nâpêsis k-âyât ,
nimisê ! itiskih ,
hâ ! kik-êtâw , itêw ôhi ayîsiyinîhkânah . “When that boy who is here says to you, ‘Sister!’ then ‘Yes!’ you will say to him,” she told that effigy.

tâpwê êkos îsi isi-wêpinêw ôhi otawâsimisah , namoya kayâs ê-kîh-nôkohât . And so in this wise she abandoned her child which not long before she had borne. LB on {isi-wêpinêw}: Hyphen is used, because the meaning is here {isi}: “thither, thus” plus {wêpinêw}: “she abandons him.” By contrast, the very common unit word {isiwêpinêw}: “he throws him that way or there” has {-wêp-}: “throw” as a non-initial stem. This illustrates the difficulty of drawing a clear line between simple words and compounds; for a native speaker it would be easy. The repetition of {isi} is worth noting; it is perhaps due to the existence of the much commoner homonym; as homonymy is rare in Cree, the combination {isi-wêpinêw} is inadequate and disturbs the speaker.
êkwah kîtahtawê kinwês êh-wâ-wêwêpitôt , kîtahtawê mah-mâtôyiwa . Then presently, when for a long time he had rocked the babe, it began to cry. CHECK wewepitot, CHECK reduplication length
têpwêw awa nâpêsis . The boy called.
nimisê , ntihkwatim mâtôw ! itwêw êsah . “Sister, my nephew is crying!” he called.
cêskwah ! nimêkwâ-nikohtân ! itik êsa ôhi ayîsiyinîhkânah kâ-kîh-osîhimiht . “Wait a bit! I am in the midst of gathering wood!” he was answered by that effigy which had been made.
piyisk êkwâh tipiskâyiw . At last darkness came.
piyisk êkwah wîh-kawaciwak . In time they were almost freezing.
mâh-mâtôwak ôhi osk-awâsisah kâ-kiki-wêpiniht . They wept, he and the babe with which he had been abandoned.
êh-kîh-nêwo-tipiskâyik , kîtahtawê piyêsiwah mistahi kâ-pêhtâkosiyit . When the fourth night had passed, suddenly the Thunderer's loud roar was heard.
kayahtê piko ôtah kîh-apiyiwa . Suddenly, there he sat.
tâpwê mistahi kikitimâkisin , nîstâh , itik êsa ôhi piyêsiwa ; “Truly, you are in a sorry plight, my brother-in-law,” the Thunderer said to him;
âsay anih mînah onâpêmiw kimis , itik ôhi piyêsiwa ; “Your sister by this time has taken another husband,” the Thunderer told him;

seg.gloss: “But I have come to fetch this your nephew.

p.seg: namoya misawâc ka-kîh-pamihtwâson , itik êsah . In any case you would not be able to take care of him,” he told him.
êkwah otayôwinisah ispimihk kâ-kîh-akotâwiht nâh-nîhtinamâk ôhi piyêsiwah . Then that Thunderer took down for him his clothes which had been hung high.
mayaw ê-kîh-postayôwinisêt , êkosi atih-otinêyiwa ôhi apisis-awâsisah . As soon as he had put them on, the other took away that infant.
wist êkwah wayawîw . He too went forth.
otasâmah ê-kîh-otinât , kâ-wâpahtahk êsa itêh omisah êy-isih-sipwêhtêyit . When he had taken up his snowshoes, he saw the say along which his sister must have departed.
kapê-kîsik pimipahtâw . He ran on, all day.

kîtahtawê êsah êh-at-ôtâkosiniyik , ôtah wayâhcâhk kîh-têpâpahtam maskosîwakân . Presently, towards evening, there in a hollow of the land, he spied a grass hut. LB on {maskosîwakân}: Normal form doubtless {maskosîwikân}, and below, the diminutive, normal: {maskosîwikânis}.
at-îtohtêw . He approached it.
hwâ , êwakw êtokê nimis wîkih ! itwêw êsah . “There, this must be my sister's dwelling!” he said.
pîhtokêw . He went inside.
pônam . He built up the fire.
êh-kîh-pônahk , pa-pimisin . When he had built up the fire, he lay there.
êsah êh-ayîtâpit , kîtahtawê omisa tôhtôsimiyiwa kâ-wâpamât , êsah ê-kîh-maniswâyit . As he looked about him, presently, there he saw his sister's breast, which she must have cut off.
wahwâ , tâpwê nikîsinâcihik ! itêyihtam êsah ; “Alas, truly she brings me to grief!” he thought;
êkwah êwakonih nika-kîh-ohci-kâkîcihâhtay nitihkwatim ka-pi-maskamikawiyân ! itêyihtam êsa . “Now with this I could have consoled my nephew that has been taken from me!” he thought.
êkwah êkotah kapêsiw . Then there he spent the night.
kâkisêpâ mîna sâsay sipwêhtêw . In the morning he set out again.
aspin êsah omisah itah ê-kih-at-îtohtêyit , kapê-kîsik ati-mâtahêw . Along the path that his sister had taken from there, he tracked her all the day.
âsay mîna êh-otâkosiniyik , kotak mîna kâ-wâpahtahk maskosiyokânis . Again, towards evening, he saw another little lodge of grass.
pîhtokêw . He entered it.
pônam . He fed the fire.
âsay mîna êh-pa-pimisihk , kotakah kâ-wâpamât omisah tôhtôsimiyiwa . Again, as he lay there, he saw his sister's other breast.
âsay mîna mihtâtam ê-kîh-pê-nâtimiht otihkwatima . Again he lamented that his nephew had been fetched away.
sipwêhtêw kîkisêpâh . He set out in the morning.

kîtahtawê êh-pi-pmohtêt , kîtahtawê kâ-sâkêwêt , ôtah mîkiwâhp , kâ-wâpamât omisah pahkêkin ê-mêkwâw-osihtâyit . Presently, as he went on, he came out upon a place where was a lodge, and there he saw his sister tanning a hide.
êkos îsi têpwâtêw . At once he called to her.

êkwah ômisih itwêw aw ôskinîkiskwêw :
namoy âwiyak nôh-osîmisin . Then that young woman said, “I have never had any younger brother.
êkos ôma pikoh êh-kiy-isi-pêyakoyân , itwêw êsah aw ôskinîkiskwêw . I have always been alone, as I am,” said the young woman.
tâpwê niya nikîh-pê-maskamikawin ntihkwatim , itwêw êsah . “As for me, truly, my nephew was taken away from me as I came,” he said.
sêmâk kisiwâsiw awa oskinîkiskwêw . At once the young woman grew angry.
môskîstawêw ôhi nâpêsisah , cîkahikan êw-ohci-pakamahwât , êh-nipahât . She ran at the boy and struck him with an ax, killing him.
mitonih pîkinatahwêw . She chopped him to bits.
mâka wiya ê-kisêwâtisicik sawêyimêwak âpakosîsak , ê-wîh-kakwê-pimâcihâcik ôhi kâ-nipahimiht nâpêsisah . But some kind mice took pity on him, deciding to try to revive that boy who had been killed.

êkwah tâpwê ,
niya nik-âwatâw ! itwêw êsa itôwâhk kâ-misikiticik âpakosîs . Then, accordingly, “I, I shall take him away!” said a mouse, one of those which are large.
tâpwê êsah nanâpâcihêwak . Accordingly, they attended to him.

ayisk kayâs kih-ayîsiyiniwiwak ; osâm kahkiyaw kêkwayih êh-wîcihikôwisicik , êyak ôhci k-ôh-îspayik . For of old they had human form; because by all the Higher Powers they were aided is why it could happen so. CHECK kekwayi
tâpwê pimâcihêwak . Really they restored him to life.

êkwah kîkisêpâ awa nâpêw kâ-wîwit ôhih oskinîkiskwêwa kâ-môhcôwiyit , osîmisiyiwa kâ-nipahâyit , ômis îtêw :
ntaw-âsamik ôki âpakosîsi-nôtokêwak , itêw êsah . Then, in the morning, that man who had to wife the young woman who was so mad and had slain her brother, spoke thus to her: “Go feed those Old Mouse Women,” he told her.
êkwah tâpwê ntaw-âsamêw awa oskinîkiskwêw . Then accordingly, the young woman went to give them food.
êh-pîhtokêt , kâ-wâpamât ôhih ka-kîh-nipahât nâpêsisah . When she entered, there she saw the boy she had killed.
âsay êcik ôki mîna êh-kîh-pimâcihâcik maci-nôtokêsiwak ! itwêw êsah . “So it seems that these evil old women have brought him back to life!” she said.

êkwah ômisih itwêw awa nâpêw :
kiyâm êkâyah , niwîkimâkan . Then the man said, “Never mind, do not kill him, my wife.
kêyiwêhk anah nka-wîcêwâw miyâciyâni , itêw . After all, I can take him with me when I hunt,” he told her.
êkosi pônihêw aw ôskinîkiskwêw . So the young woman left him alone.
êkwah tâpwê ôki nôtokêwak wawayîhêwak ôsisimiwâwa , ta-mâciyit . Then, accordingly, the old women made their grandchild ready, that he might hunt.

tâpwê awa nâpêw ê-wîh-mâcît ,
âstam , wêskinîkiyin ! So, when that man was ready to go hunting, “Come here, young fellow!

iskêkânê nahâhkapiyani , itâw aw âwâsis . It would seem you are staying with people,” the child was told. LB on {nahâhkapiyani}: The verb {nahâhkapiw}: “he is staying, as son-in-law, with his wife's people”; it applied here only in so far as during this stay a son-in-law is supposed to show himself a good worker. Irony.
êkwah tâpwê wawêyîw awa awâsis , êkwah ê-sipwêhtêcik , ôhih êh-wîcêwât ôhi nâpêwah , êh-mâciyit . Then the child made himself ready, and they set out, as he accompanied that man on his hunt.

iyâtah-mâtahâtwâwi ,
namoy êwako , itik mâna ; Although they would come upon some creature's trail, “Not this one,” the other would say to him;
osâm apisîsisiw , itik mâna . “He is too small,” the other would say to him.

êkwah tâpwê kotakah mitonih êh-mâh-mâhkiskamiyit , êwakonih êti-pimitisahwâyit mis-iyâpêw-wawâskêsiwah , wîpac êti-nipahâyit . Then really, when they saw the trail of another whose tracks were of enormous size, then the man went off pursuing this giant stag, and soon off there slew him.
nâway êh-takohtêt , âsay kêkâc kîsi-wiyanihêyiwa . When the boy later arrived, the other had almost finished preparing the carcass.

êkwah ômisi itik :
nawacî ôma otakisiy , itik . Then the man told him, “Roast this tripe,” he told him.
tâpwê nawacîw . So he roasted it.

êkwah êh-kîsisahk , ômisi itêw :
hâyîtaw ohcih kika-mîcinânaw , itêw . When he had cooked it done, he said to the man, “Let us eat it from either end.”

êkwah ,
tânêhki k-ôh-itwêyin ? itwêw awa nâpêw ; Then, “What makes you say that?” said the man;
kiy ôma kitawâsisin , mistahi kâ-ntawêyihtaman kita-mîciyan , itêw êsa . “You, you are but a child, to be wanting to eat so much,” he told him.
mâka ayisk namoya nikaskihtamâson kêkway , itwêw awa nâpêsis . “But since I have no power of any kind!” said the boy.
êhag , itik . “Yes, very well,” the other said to him.
tâpwê êh-kîsisahk ôma mayaw otakisiy , tâpwê âyîtaw ohcih miciminamwak , êh-mîccik . Accordingly, as soon as he had cooked done that tripe, they each took hold of an end, and ate it.
êkwah kêkâc êh-kitâcik , maskamêw . Then, when they had almost eaten it up, he snatched it away from the man.
hâw , ôma mîcih , piyêsiw ! itwêw êsah . “Come, eat this, Thunderer!” he said.
ôh , kêkway itah kê-kitimâkêyimikoyan ? itik êsah ôhi nâpêwa ; “Ho, what sort of thing will give its aid to you?” the man said to him;
ati-pasikôw ! itik êsah . “Up with you!” he told him.
tah kisiwâk ostikwân ohpimê êh-astêyik , otinamiyiwa itêh isi k-êsi-kâsitêskanêyit ; Close by there, off to one side, where lay the stag's head, the man took it up by the beast's pointed horns;
nayahtahik . he put it on the boy's back, for him to carry.
kawiskôsôw . He sank to the ground under the weight.
pasikôh ! itik : “Get up!” he told him;

seg.q: m âni âtah êh-manitôwakêyimoyin , itah wiya at-âtimitâni , kika-nipahitin ;
seg.gloss: “Believe it or not, though you think yourself of manitou kind, if I overtake you on the way, I will kill you;
I will stamp you under my snowshoes.”
seg.note: LB on {kik-âti-patakwâkimatitin}: The medial stem is {-âkimê-}: “snowshoe” (verbal), cf. Ojibwa {âgim}, Menomini {âkim} (animate): “snowshoe.” The word used in Cree is {asâm} (animate): “snowshoe.” I did not catch the word when dictated, but succeeded in making informant repeat it. As a result it is not used in the recurrence of the incident, below.
CHECK whether lexicon has typo - LB's note implies stem should have {-âkim-}

p.seg: tâpwê ati-sipwêhtêw awa nâpêsis . So the boy started off.
cîki wîkiwâhk êh-at-âyât , âsay kisiwâk kâ-pêcâstamohtêyit , êh-atimikot . When he had got close to their lodge, the other had already come near, and now overtook him.
êkos îsi sâ-sâkwâkimâtik . At once he crushed him under his snowshoes.
êkwah êsah nipahik ; êskanah kâ-kîhcitâskamâk . He killed him; he jabbed the horns into him.
êkwah mistahi miywêyihtam awa oskinîkiskwêw , nôhtaw êh-pê-nipahimiht . Then the young woman was very glad that he had been killed before reaching the place.

êkwah âsay mîna ôki nôtokêsiwak kâ-kîh-pimâtisihâcik mîna itwêwak ,
pêyakwâw ta-kakwê-pimâcihâcik ! Then again those old women who had restored him to life said, “Let them try once more to bring him to life!”
tâpwê awa kâ-misikitit nôtokêw âpakosîsi-nôtokêw âwatêw êwako . Then, accordingly, that big old woman, that Old Mouse Woman took him off with her.
tâpwê âsay mîna pimâcihêwak . they succeeded in bringing him again to life.
êsa mâna wâh-pimâcihâtwâwi , matotisiwak . It seems that they took a steam-bath whenever they were about to bring him to life.

êkwah âsay mîna kîkisêpâ ,
ntaw-asam kôhkominawak , itwêw êsah awa nâpêw . Then again, in the morning, “Go feed our grandmothers,” said the man.
tâpwê êh-itohtêt awa oskinîkiskwêw , kîh-pimâtisiyiwa ôhi nâpêsisah . When, accordingly, the young woman went there, the boy was alive.

seg.gloss: “And so they have done it again!

p.seg: nikîh-miywêyihtamwah êh-nipahimiht ! itwêw êsah . I was glad he had been killed!” she exclaimed.
kiyâm êkos âna pêyakwâw mîna nika-wîcêwâw , itwêw awa nâpêw . “Never mind, I shall simply take him with me again,” said the man.
tâpwêh pônihêw awa oskinîkiskwêw . Then the young woman left him alone.
êkwah wawiyîw awa nâpêsis . Then the boy made ready.
mâcîwak . They went hunting.
pê-wîsâmik ôhi nâpêwah . The man came to take him along.
âsay mîna mâtahêwak wawâskêsiwah . again they came upon the trail of a stag.

awa cî ? êh-âtiy-itât ,
namoya ! osâm apisîsisiw , itik . “Is this the one?” he asked him, but, “No! He is too small,” the other answered.

mitonih nâspic ê-mâh-mâhkiskamiyit , êwakonih pêmitisahwâyit ,
itâp kika-pêy-âtimin , itik . When one had left hoofprints of enormous size, this one the man pursued; “You will catch up to me later,” he told him.
tâpwê mwêstas êkotê êh-takohtêt , âsay kêkâc kîsi-wiyanihêyiwa . Truly, later, when the boy got there, he had already nearly finished cleaning the carcass.

âsay mîna ,
hâw , awâsis , ôma nawacî ; Again, “Come, child, roast this;
mîcîhkahk ôma otakisih , itik êsa . let us later eat this tripe,” he told him.

tâpwê ,
âyîtaw ohcih mîna kika-mîcinânaw , itêw êsa . Then, “Let us eat it again from either end,” he told the man.

tâpwê ,
nîswâw êkwah êkosi kititwân , itik êsa . Then, “Now for the second time you say thus,” the other answered him.
ayisk niya nikitimâkisin , itwêw êsah awa nâpêsis . “After all, as for me, I am but a poor creature,” said the boy.
êhag , itwêw êsa awa nâpêw . “Yes, very well,” said the man.

êkwah tâpwê ,
itêh niya k-êsi-misâk , êkotê isi niya nik-êsi-mîcin , itwêw awa nâpêsis . Then, “Let me have the big end, let me eat from the big end,” said the boy.
piyisk mîna sâkôcimêw . At last he talked the man into it.
êkwah tâpwê âyîtaw ohci miciminamwak êh-mîcicik . So then they took hold of it at either end and ate it.
apisîs êy-iskwahtahkik , ispimihk isiwêpinam awa nâpêsis . When they had but a little uneaten, the boy flung it aloft.

haw , ôma mîcih , itwêw êsah ,
piyêsiw ! itwêw êsah . “Come, eat this,” he said, “O Thunderer!”
êkwah âsay mîna ohpimê astêyiw ôma ostikwân , âsay mîna êwakoh k-ôtinamiyit , ê-nayahtahikot . Now again, off to one side lay the head, and again the man took it and put it on the boy's back.

âsay mîna pasikôtisahok ,
kakwayahoh ! êh-itikot . Again he drove him to his feet, telling him, “Look lively!”
êkwah ati-sipwêhtêw . He started out.
mitonih papâsimik . The man hurried him on with shouts.
kîspin itah atimitâni , kik-âti-mâtakoskâtn ntasâmak ohci ! itik êsah . “If anywhere I catch you, I will stamp you flat with my snowshoes!” he called to him.
tâpwê sipwêhtêw . He went off.
kisiwâk êkwa wîkiwâhk êh-at-âyât , kâ-pêh-atimikot . When he had got near the lodge, the other overtook him.

ômisi itwêw êsah ê-wîh-pê-nipahikot :
piyêsiw , êyakw âna nipahtamawin ! niwîh-nipahik ! itwêw awa nâpêsis . As the other was about to come upon him and kill him, he cried, “Thunderer, kill this one for me! He wants to kill me!” said the boy.
êkwa tâpwê piyêsiwak sôhki pêhtâkosiwak . Then truly the Thunderers made themselves loudly heard.
nipahêwak ôhih nâpêwah , awâsisah kâ-wîh-nipahâyit . They killed that man who was going to kill the child.
êkosi pê-wayawî-kwâskohtiw aw ôskinîkiskwêw . Then the young woman came leaping out of her dwelling.
âsay mîna kîhtwâm nipahêw ôhi osîmisah . Again she slew her little brother.
kîhtwâm êkwah pimâcihâyêkoh , ka-mêhcihitinâwâw ! itêw ôhi nôtokêsiwah . “If you again restore him to life, I will kill you all!” she said to those old women.

haw , itwêwak ôki nôtokêwak ,
misawâc namoya ta-kîh-nipahikonaw . “Now,” said those old women, “in any case she will not be able to kill us.
kiyâm kêyâpic pêyakwâw pimâcihâtân , itwêwak . Let us revive him once more,” they said.
tâpwê mîna sâsay osîhtâwak ôma mâna itah kâ-pimâcihâcik . Accordingly, again they built that in which they always revived him.
tâpwê kîsihtâwak . They completed it.
âsay mîna kikisêpâh ê-ntawâpamât , êh-pimâtisiyit ôhi nâpêsisah awa oskinîkiskwêw , kakwê-nipahêw . When the young woman went to see them in the morning, and the boy was alive, she tried to kill him.

mwêhci ê-wîh-nipahât ,
awa niwîh-nipahik , piyêsiwitik ! asay mînah itwêw awa nâpêsis . Just as she was about to slay him, “This one means to kill me, O Thunderers!” the boy said again.
tâpwê mistahi pêhtâkosiwak piyêsiwak . Truly with great noise the Thunderers were heard.
ntawâc ôtêh ispimihk kit-êsi-kîwêhtahitân , itwêw awa piyêsiw ; “I shall needs take you home with me aloft,” said the one Thunderer;

seg.gloss: “I have already brought to maturity your nephew whom I took.

p.seg: ôma k-êsinâkosiyân , êkosi wîstah isinâkosiw , itik ôhi piyêsiwa . Even as I look, so looks he too,” the Thunderer said to him.
tâpwê sipwêhtahik ; ati-wêpinik piyêsiwacistwanihk . So he took him away from there; he dropped him into a Thunderer's-nest.
êkwah êkotah tahtwâw êh-kîh-nêwo-tipiskâyik , êkospihk êsa ôhi kîs-ôhpikiw êh-piyêsiwit . And there, when four nights had passed, by that time he had grown to maturity as a Thunderer.
êwako pêyak âcimôwin . That is one tale.
